title: Foster the People's 'Sacred Hearts Club' is a Fun Ride
summary: Foster the People's new album is reminiscent of classic rock bands like Pink Floyd and Led Zeppelin. Artists often write about the things they experienced in their youth, so it makes sense that your artistic career is shaped by your formative years. When you're writing songs, you’re likely to explore what you were experiencing during that time. It’s healthy for artists to push their own boundaries, and artists who want to experiment with new sounds should consider releasing their music independently – this will allow you to fully explore your creative vision.

const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"Nostalgia can be a beautiful thing."),mdx("p",null,`When nostalgia becomes a creative fuel, it\u2019s a beautiful thing. This is especially true for artists who revisit the music of their youth. Many artists \u2013 including Foster the People \u2013 first got their start in garage bands in their teens.
If you\u2019re an artist seeking inspiration, it can be helpful to think back to your high school years. Foster the People\u2019s album is reminiscent of classic rock bands like Pink Floyd and Led Zeppelin. In fact, \u201CHustling\u201D features a saxophone solo that sounds eerily similar to Pink Floyd\u2019s \u201CMoney\u201D. It might seem like a stretch, but artists like Pink Floyd and the Beatles have always served as inspiration for musicians. You might not be the next Zeppelin or Floyd, but you can certainly be inspired by them.`),mdx("h2",null,"It helps you reconnect with your youth."),mdx("p",null,"When artists go back to their roots, they\u2019re often reconnecting with the musical vision they had as a teenager. Artists often write about the things they experienced in their youth, so it makes sense that your artistic career is shaped by your formative years. When you\u2019re writing songs, you\u2019re likely to explore what you were experiencing during that time."),mdx("p",null,"If you\u2019re an artist who wants to get back to your roots, start by exploring what was going on in your life during that time. Foster the People\u2019s album certainly reflects the band\u2019s youth. The LP\u2019s theme is tied to the California license plate \u201CSLOMO\u201D \u2013 a reference to the band\u2019s time spent in Los Angeles. It\u2019s possible that the band members were inspired by their experiences living in the city, which brings us back to the previous point."),mdx("h2",null,"Sometimes going back to the basics is exactly what you need."),mdx("p",null,"If you find yourself in a creative rut, consider taking a step back and simplifying your process. For example, make a list of your favorite artists in the world, and ask yourself why you\u2019re a fan. This can help you engage with your core audience."),mdx("p",null,"Foster the People's list of influences for this album include Pink Floyd and Weezer. At their core, these artists are great songwriters. The best way to get back to the basics is to focus on your craft and come up with a bunch of killer songs."),mdx("p",null,"If you want to get back to the basics but aren\u2019t sure where to start, try writing lyrics without the music. This will help you identify what you\u2019re really feeling. You can then take these emotions and use them to create music."),mdx("h2",null,"It\u2019s healthy for artists to push their own boundaries."),mdx("p",null,`When artists go back to their roots, they\u2019re often looking to push their boundaries. We\u2019re all familiar with the saying, \u201CIf you do what you\u2019ve always done, you\u2019ll get what you\u2019ve always gotten.\u201D But in this case, it might be exactly what you need.
When Foster the People released their debut album in 2011, the music was very accessible. The album was heavy on pop, alternative and dance sounds. The band\u2019s new album, \u2018Sacred Hearts Club\u2019, is much more experimental. Tracks like \u201CPay the Man\u201D are multi-layered and heavy on psychedelic sounds.`),mdx("p",null,"When artists push their own boundaries, there\u2019s a good chance listeners will respond. Artists who want to experiment with new sounds should consider releasing their music independently \u2013 this will allow you to fully explore your creative vision."),mdx("h2",null,"You\u2019ll have a whole new set of tools to work with."),mdx("p",null,`When artists go back to their roots, they often discover they now have a whole new set of tools to work with. The best way to put this into practice is to start listening to music that inspired your favourite artists, but also look at the artists who were inspired by those artists.
This is a cyclical process that can help you get inspired and create something new. Foster the People has done just that. Take the track \u201CLoyal Like Sid and Nancy\u201D and the track \u201CFireflies\u201D by Owl City. These songs are very similar to \u201CLoyal Like Sid and Nancy\u201D, and both songs were written and released before \u201CLoyal Like Sid and Nancy\u201D.`),mdx("p",null,"You might not be able to create an album as thematically and sonically consistent as \u2018Sacred Hearts Club\u2019, but you can certainly pull a few tricks from Foster the People\u2019s playbook."),mdx("h2",null,"You\u2019ll discover your core listeners respond to most."),mdx("p",null,`When artists go back to their roots, they\u2019re often looking for inspiration. But along the way, they might discover that their core listeners respond to something specific in their music. This could be anything from a particular melody to an element of your lyrics.
When Foster the People created their debut album, they knew they wanted certain songs to be singles. The band even used click tracks to make sure they hit the beats they wanted. But on their new album, they displayed a certain level of spontaneity.`),mdx("p",null,"For example, the track \u201CPay the Man\u201D begins with an improvised saxophone solo. It\u2019s possible that the band members were inspired by their youth and wanted to experiment. If this is the case, it\u2019s possible that your core listeners respond to your experimentation. And that\u2019s a good thing! It means you\u2019re staying true to yourself."),mdx("h2",null,"Conclusion"),mdx("p",null,"Foster the People's latest album is a fun ride through the group's youth. When artists go back to their roots, they're often looking to push their boundaries. Artists who want to experiment with new sounds should consider releasing their music independently to give them full creative freedom. When artists get back to their roots, they discover they now have a whole new set of tools to work with. When artists go back to their roots, they're often looking to push their boundaries. relatedArticles.title: The History of Hip Hop Music: The Influential Years

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Hip hop music is a universal language. It has proven to be a way for people from different cultures and backgrounds to come together and express themselves. From its humble beginnings in New York City, hip hop has grown into a worldwide sensation, with local scenes spawning in cities across the globe. This article explores the history of hip-hop music, from its roots as an underground movement in the early 1980s to its predominance as one of the most popular genres today.
Fans of rap music are undoubtedly aware that this style of music has origins in New York City during the 1970s and 1980s, but there is much more to know about how exactly it came about and how it evolved over time. From breakdancing to rapping, we\u2019ll explore all of the elements that blended together to form what we now call \u201Chip-hop\u201D today.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Charlie Puth's 'Voicenotes' Is a Solid Effort

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:t,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Charlie Puth has been on a roll lately, with three top 40 hits in the last two years. He\u2019s also worked with some pretty big names (including one we\u2019ll get to shortly). Now, he\u2019s back with another new album, titled \u201CVoicenotes.\u201D It\u2019s a solid effort that shows growth and maturity, as well as keeping Puth\u2019s fun and lighthearted style.
At its core, Voicenotes is an acoustic pop album. However, it goes deeper than just putting electric guitars aside; these songs are stripped right down to the bare bones. There\u2019s still plenty of production value\u2014especially on the third track\u2014but it feels like Puth made a conscious decision not to hide behind anything.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: "The Babadook" Is a Haunting and Original Horror Film
9 of the Best Hip Hop Songs for Your Next Workout
Why Hip Hop Music Rules the World
"The Big Short" Is a Searing Indictment of the Financial Industry

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`The film version of The Big Short hits theaters this Friday, and it\u2019s not subtle. Its tagline is \u201CThere\u2019s a sucker born every minute. But they don\u2019t grow up thinking they can be con men. They get taught to be one.\u201D And its trailer goes on to say, \u201CThe housing bubble was about to burst\u2026 And a group of misfits saw it coming. Now these unlikely heroes must band together and bring down the greedy villains who crashed the world economy\u2026 Before anyone else gets hurt.\u201D
Unfortunately, that last part is not hyperbole. The actions of unscrupulous financial engineers \u2014 colloquially known as \u201Cbankers\u201D \u2014 led directly to the Great Recession in 2008, which cost millions their jobs and homes, while triggering widespread deflation and anemic growth throughout much of the developed world for years thereafter.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: "The Imitation Game" Is a Fascinating Look at the Life of Alan Turing

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`In 1937, Alan Turing was born in Northern England. He would go on to become a war hero, pioneer of computer science, and one of the greatest minds of the 20th century. In 1951, he was convicted of \u201Cgross indecency\u201D and chemically castrated as punishment. Two years later, he killed himself with cyanide. This is his story.
Turing was a brilliant man with many interests that went beyond mathematics and computer science: chess, cryptography, music theory and programming computers to sing are just some examples. This diverse background helped him crack the Nazi Enigma code during World War II at Bletchley Park (which has been nicknamed "Codebreaking Castle"). This saved countless lives and accelerated the end of the war by two years. After the war ended in 1945, Turing continued working as an cryptanalyst for a few more years before turning his attention to other interests \u2013- and it is these interests that led to his arrest and untimely death at age 41.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Father John Misty's 'Pure Comedy' Is a Hilarious Masterpiece
"The Martian" Is a Triumph of Science Fiction

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Ridley Scott\u2019s new movie, The Martian, is based on a novel of the same name by Andy Weir. It\u2019s about an astronaut called Mark Watney who gets stranded on Mars after his crewmates think he\u2019s dead and leave without him. This might seem as just another case of annoying Hollywood over-simplification: after all, we get so many bioengineered super-geniuses with computer uplink implants that they can become trapped in remote locations via their own stupidity. But there\u2019s more to it than that.
In both book and film, the humanity of Watney comes out in everything he does to survive: logical thinking (how can I eat this potato again?), ingenuity (I need water; how do I distill it from our CO2 filters), courage (explore the abandoned outpost), and compassion (contact my family). He also has a lot of fun with his predicament, cracking jokes through his video log and even going disco.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
